comment_0:
Okay guys, I'm pretty positive on this meaning.  This isn't my own interpretation, therefore I do not take credit for it, but I do agree with it.
  Okay, about the meaning from toolshed.down.net... it's partly true, but not completely.  Ya ever wonder why they just DO NOT play that song on tour, like hardly at all, even though it's so popular?  Well it's because this song has a special meaning to Maynard.
    Devo Keenan, his son, has the middle name of H... not anything extra... just H.  The song isn't about any person at all, it's about his son... think about the song.  Maynard had a bad relationship with his father when he was young, constantly being abused.  Even though he loves Devo, sometimes he has a problem, and wants to hurt him.  He gets it from his father... and it causes him to want to lash out at his wife and his child. that's why when he says they're "void of hate, but killing him just the same"... he means that Devo loves him, but he's still hurting Maynard because of Maynard's past.... 
  When he talks about "snake behind me hisses, what my damage could have been", he's talkin about how what his father did to him wants to resurge through him and onto Devo.  then the next verse "my blood before me begs me, open up my heart again"... he's sayin that the blood before him (his children, future grandchildren, etc.) is begging him to forget the past and start over... Infer the rest of the song for yourself.  I think this is the best explanation possible.  Thanks for botherin to read this.
comment_1:
Most say this song is about his son, name being Devo H. Keenan (initial only)

"Maynard" is name James picked up at Westpoint, he was born James "H"erbert Keenan.

He wrote this song while his girlfriend was pregnant with his child, and it is about the storm of emotion bred up inside him over conflicting feelings of perpetuating the abuse he suffered at the hands of his stepfather, and a desire to overcome these worries of "Do unto others, what they have don to you" (perpetuating the cycle of abuse) and raise his child with love. "H" is about Maynard struggling with his soon to collide past and present, and his realization in the face of it, that he can do it.

It is the price you pay for being close to them; they aren't doing it on purpose: "considerately" ~ from the toolshed.down.net FAQ
comment_3:
Like i've read here and there this song is actually about Maynard's son, whose second name is âHâ. But I think that's not exactly about the fear to replicate upon his own son the violence that he himself has suffered from his father.
I think that the lyric involves directly or indirectly 4 charachters:
Maynard : who is the center of an inner conflict.
The snake : Personification of Maynard's hate, rage, and revenge feelings for what he suffered when he was a child
Maynard's father 
Maynard's son.
Keeping these in mind, all we have to do is understand sentence by sentence whom the song is referring to.

>>> âWhat's coming through is alive. What's holding up is a mirror.â

Maynard's son lead Maynard to look at himself and think again about his sad childhood.

>>> âBut what's singing songs is a snake. Looking to turn my piss to wine.â

The snake is the temptation to indulge in hate and resentment, making them look like pleasant feelings (piss to wine).

>>> âThey're both totally void of hate, But killing me just the same.â

That's referred to the snake and the father.

>>> The snake behind me hisses What my damage could have done. â

That's ambiguois. I think the âdamageâ could be the mark of the father on Maynard, the fact that his personality changed in worst because he became full of hate, resentment, etc.

>>> My blood before me begs me Open up my heart again.

But his inner voice (me) and his son (my blood) beg him to not let his father, the hate and resentment win, but to open his heart instead.

>>> And I feel this coming over like a storm again. Considerately.

All the fear, inner conflicts, rage, etc. that he experienced in the past as his father came to beat him are happening once again in his mind.

>>> Venomous voice, tempts me, Drains me, bleeds me. Leaves me cracked and empty. Drags me down like some sweet gravity.

As above the snake is the temptation to indulge in anger and bad feelings instead of fighting them.

>>>  I am too connected to you. To slip away, fade away. Days away I still feel you. Touching me, changing me. Considerately killing me.

That's the climax of the inner fight: Maynard is scared that the past hurted him to deeply and too much, so that's impossible for him to change, to forget.

>>> Without the skin here, Beneath the storm. Under these tears now, The walls came down. And as the snake is drowned And as I look in his eyes, My fear begins to fade Recalling all of those times. I could have cried then. I should have cried then. (â¦) I have died and will die. It's all right. (I don't mind)

At the end Maynard won the fight, he is reborn: all the anger that surrond him like walls are gone, the snake that tempted him is gone.  He look in his son's eyes in order to find the strenght to change and let the good feelings win. But even if he won this fight he can't erase what happened: he still recall those days, he still remember all the bad feelings he had to hide, all the time he wanted to cry, all the time that he died inside. And every time he will remember what happened he will die inside once again.

After all this song is pretty similar to âReflectionâ: both describes an inner fight against bad feelings (anger and resentment / selfishness and sloth), and both ends up with the win of the good side of the soul. (âAnd as I pull my head out I am without one doubt. Don't wanna be down here feeding my narcissismâ /  âWithout the skin here, Beneath the storm. Under these tears now, The walls came down. And as the snake is drowned And as I look in his eyes, My fear begins to fadeâ)
comment_4:
This song sounds, to me, like the trials of being addicted to heroin. Of course the song is H. which is slang for heroin but put it in deeper meaning: 

"What's coming through is alive.
What's holding up is a mirror.
But what's singing songs is a snake
Looking to turn this piss to wine. "

The snake is the needle, here to help numb my pains, a great numbing sensation this is, its turning my piss to wine.

"And I feel this coming over like a storm again.
Considerately."

This is my withdrawals, being sucked back to the needle. As hard as I try to stay away for my own concern and the concern of my loved ones, I keep being sucked back.

Venomous voice, tempts me,
Drains me, bleeds me,
Leaves me cracked and empty.
Drags me down like some sweet gravity. 

The drug wont let me go, its destroying my life but I cant, for the life of me, get away. I need it so bad, I want to get away but it keeps calling my back.

"I am too connected to you to
Slip away, to fade away.
Days away I still feel you
Touching me, changing me,
And considerately killing me."

I dont know life without you, now that I am clean, I dont know what to do but be depressed, this depression is killing me as bad as you were once killing me. I still want you so badly, I feel you trying to come back into my life.

"Without the skin,
Beneath the storm,
Under these tears
The walls came down."

I am hopeless, I am weak and I am open, I cannot proceed. The walls are coming down. This is my withdrawal.

"And the snake is drowned and
As I look in his eyes,
My fear begins to fade
Recalling all of those times.

I could have cried then.
I should have cried then. "

My sweet, sweet relapse. I miss you so much. I hate the fact I am doing this, but I need it so bad, I shouldnt have done this.


This is the best part of any song I have ever experienced. I love this line so much, it is so compassionate, so deep. I listen to this song every single day and the moment this line comes on, my heart sinks:

"And as the walls come down and
As I look in your eyes
My fear begins to fade
Recalling all of the times
I have died
and will die.
It's all right.
I don't mind. "


This is it, Im hooked again. I've already relapsed, there is no turning back now, and you know what? I really dont mind anymore. This is all I know so this is all I will stick to. I'm dead inside, I have nothing more to give, nothing more to live for but this drug.

Sincerely,
 Lafayette

I know addiction, I know the effect it holds on someone, and this song sounds to me like my own compassionate addiction which may be why I love this song with all my heart.
comment_5:
It's pretty obvious-- this song is about Maynard's son. He is tempted (by the snake, his father, with whom he had an abusive relationship) to distance himself from this child. He realizes, however, that his former relationship with his father is a thing of the past, and he has the opportunity to kill the tendencies he could have inherited from his father by opening his heart and being vulnerable in having a loving relationship with his child. Simple as that.

I also think that the song might have been different if Maynard had a daughter instead.
comment_6:
The working title of the song was "Half Here" - on several tours MJK has referenced his son before performing the song as well as saying something along the lines of it being similar to the angel and devil sitting on characters shoulders in cartoons and that they're really just friends.

My interpretation of everything is this - in the song he is referencing two individuals. They are his son, who he is speaking to and a part of himself that isn't ready to be a father.

He is having a conflict between the part of him that's ready to be a father and the one that's not (the snake). He's been having it since he found out he was going to have a child. 

Beneath the storm is referencing his final "break down" after his son is born. He's realizing and understanding the fearful part of himself is the problem. He's understanding that he could have done this at any time.

He looks at his son and remembers the other times he has "had" to change(die) and everything will be fine. Considerately killing me is his son killing "that" part of him.

I've listened to this song for maybe 15 years but this is the first time I've really felt confident about it's meaning :S

This song is NOT about heroin but rather the struggle between maintaining himself as the singer of an extremely popular rock band and being a father. The song was named H. after his son Devo H. Keenan.

"What's coming through is alive
What's holding up is a mirror"

His son being born and like a mirror image of himself or he sees himself in his son.

"But what's singing songs is a snake

This describes his other side or alter ego, the lead singer of a rock group.


The song is about facing the two parts of his life.
comment_11:
So I've been stewing on this song for a few years now (ever since i first got into tool, this has been one of my favorite of their songs), and i think I'm ready to give my interpretarion, which is sure to be unnecessarily long-winded.
No question this song is about his son at least, perhaps his entire family at the time (i believe his then wife was breÃ±a). Based on Maynards previous interviews, the H stands for devo's middle name, as others have already stated.
The entire song is loaded with imagery. But everything has a meaning, no matter how simple. My interpretation is based on something maynard said in concert in '96 to introduce this song.
Straight from wikipedia:
 "Any of you ever seen those old Warner Bros. cartoons? Sometimes there's that one where the guy is trying to make a decision, and he's got an angel on one shoulder and the devil on the other. Seems pretty obvious, right? The angel is trying to give him good advice while the devil is trying to get him to do what's bad for him. It's not always that simple, though. A lot of times they're not really angels or devils, but friends giving you advice, looking out for your best interest but not really understanding what's going to be best for you. So it kind of comes down to you. You have to make the decision yourself. This song is called 'H.'
-MJK himself
So using that quote as a framework, let's break down the song in the classic line by line style.



"What's coming through is alive
What's holding up is a mirror
But what's singing songs is a snake
Looking to turn this piss to wine"

This is very important. These first four lines are describing each side of his shoulder: one side is a mirror that's alive, a reflection of himself- in my opinion, it makes sense that that's devo: a living mirror of maynard. The other side is a snake that is looking to turn his piss into wine, i.e. a somewhat more nefarious side that's trying to turn a bad situation good.

"They're both totally void of hate
But killing me just the same"

But we have to remember what maynard says, neither side is inherently good or bad, they both care about maynard. According to this line, theyre also simultaneously doing him harm.

"The snake behind me hisses
What my damage could have been
My blood before me begs me
Open up my heart again"

So the snake is whispering what his damage could have been: how badly he could be hurt. This is integral to my theory of who or what the snake represents.
In my mind, its not his abuser, but rather, his defense mechanism against abuse. All those repressed feelings of hate and angst from being abused as a young boy in ohio created a snake-like defense mechanism in maynard that whispers at him whenever he gets too close to someone, reminding him of the danger, the possible damage.
On the opposite side is his blood before him- his son- begging him to open up his heart and emotionally connect- which is the exact thing the snake is telling him NOT to do. Ironic.

"And I feel this coming over like a storm again
Considerately"

So whenever his son and wife or anyone else is tugging at him to open up emotionally, that snake is whispering and hissing at maynard, and he feels all those feelings from the past well up and start killing him inside: condsiderately, mind you.

"Venomous voice, tempts me
Drains me, bleeds me
Leaves me cracked and empty
Drags me down like some sweet gravity"

The snake is tempting him, draining him, dragging him down: encouraging him to draw inside and away from everyone else. Cut himself off to keep from being hurt.

"I am too connected to you to
Slip away, to fade away
Days away I still feel you
Touching me, changing me
And considerately killing me"

But at the same time he knows that he's too connected to his family so slip away, and so he won't leave them. But being around them is still killing him inside, because it reminds him of his own abuse.

"Without the skin
Beneath the storm
Under these tears
The walls came down"

As he's being battered around by the storm of repressed feelings seeping out of his subconscious, he finally finds the strength inside to make his own decision and brings the emotional walls down.

"And the snake is drowned and
As I look in his eyes
My fear begins to fade
Recalling all of those times
I could have cried then
I should have cried then
And as the walls come down and
As I look in your eyes
My fear begins to fade
Recalling all of the times
I have died And will die
It's all right I don't mind"

The metaphorical storm of emotions floods out into this dreamscape and the snake- the defense mechanism that he had long since outgrown- is drowned in the torrent. As he looks in it's eyes, his fear of emotional commitment fades. He remembers the times he should have cried- the times he should have been emotionally available for his family, and uses that regret to break down his walls. As he looks in his family's eyes, he remembers all the times he almost died from the abuse of his biological father, and makes his peace with it. He no longer minds.

I am too connected to you to
Slip away, to fade away
Days away I still feel you
Touching me, changing me
And considerately killing me

So he knows the truth- that he is too connected to the ones he loves to allow them to slip away because of his own past.




That's my opinion, anyway.

comment_39:
This song's meaning depends on who analyzes it. For me this song is about love. Hear me out... I used to constantly be betrayed and hurt at the hands of people I really cared about and I built a shield. I refused to love again, that way I wouldn't have to suffer again.
This lasted for a long time and then I met a girl named Rachael (because of the way she spells her name, the middle letter is "h", weird huh?) and I refused to let myself be open with her, I wouldn't put down my guard. I held out for about 6 months, then I thought for a olng time about it, and the period that I was thinking, is like the period that the song takes place. The snake is the pain from the past and the shield that I put up, the blood before me is the desire to let go, to live again. Finally, I looked in her eyes and let go. I just gave up my shield, made myself vurnerable again. She had to do the same thing, and it worked out. Now that I finally drowned the snake, I can live again, not just with Rac"h"ael, but now I can handle fear. 

That's what this song means.

comment_62:
Madson has pinpointed the cornerstone on which the lyrical presence of this song has been founded.  Although the song may be for his son, his son's presence/person was not intended to be found in the lyrics.  This song, though, is indeed about the treacherous relationship Maynard endured with this abusive stepfather growing up.  It also happens that Maynard's original middle name was Hubert and his son's H.  The song is struggle between the past and the present, a father-son relationship.  The snake symbolizes the residual presence of Maynard's stepfather and the other person mentioned in the song symbolizes the Maynard's undaunted, unadulterated person.  When Maynards says:
What's holding up is a mirror 
But what's singing songs is a snake 
he is refering to his own person when mentioning the mirror and is refering to his stepfathers residual presence in himself when he refers to the singing snake.
Ahh....clever Maynard, clever.  But Maynard is even more clever than first thought.  A true TOOL fan knows the multiple levels on which Maynard always wrote his songs...the first and foremost being Biblical Allusions...usually relating to terrible times in his own life...Maynard trying to reveal the hypocracy of what he grew up knowing as the Chistian Baptist faith.  As we all know, Maynard was raised in a strict Baptist household growing up, but was subject to horrible sexual, verbal, and physical abuse from his stepfather...the hypocratical betrayer of his own message of love and diligence.  Maynard grew up not trusting Christianity, Baptist Christianity in particular, and even found evil and hypocracy in its God, the symbol of its values, Jesus Christ.  I believe Maynard makes a symbolic reference.  The snake symbolizes something evil, yet something that supposed to come off as being righteous, being loving...the snake symbolizes Jesus Christ, who Maynard thought to be the devil at the time and in this song.  Anyone who swears will understand the next bit.  When a man swears using the Lords name in vein, he sometimes says, "Jesus H. Christ".....ahh yes!!--the glorius connections is made.  This view of Jesus parallels the his view of his stepfather, someone who comes off loving but who betrays you at the most intimate level.  When refering to H., I believe Maynard is refering to that terrible time when that was his middle initial, and I believe that he is also refering to the negatively connotated so-called middle intitial of Christ.  He is afterall drawing parallels between the two things, that time in his life and that message in his life.  To futher provide evidence supporting the Biblical Allusion, he says:
But what's singing songs is a snake 
Looking to turn this piss to wine
which shows real animosity towards Jesus Christ, "turning this piss to wine."  You see the symbolic reference of the snake being the devil/his stepfather as well:
The snake behind [in the past now] me hisses 
What my damage could have been [if he were to be like his stepfather]
he also says:
Venomous voice [Satan's/stepfather], tempts me, 
Drains me, bleeds me, 
Leaves me cracked and empty 
Drags me down like some sweet gravity
all of these references are past and done with but still effect him immensly even today.
This explanation of H., I believe, is more thorough than what was previously stated.

ok, i got my meaning from the tool web sight. 
 Ya ever wonder why they just DO NOT play that song on tour, like hardly at all, even though it's so popular? Well it's because this song has a special meaning to Maynard. 
Devo Keenan, his son, has the middle name of H... not anything extra... just H. The song isn't about any person at all, it's about his son... think about the song. Maynard had a bad relationship with his father when he was young, constantly being abused. Even though he loves Devo, sometimes he has a problem, and wants to hurt him. He gets it from his father... and it causes him to want to lash out at his wife and his child. that's why when he says they're "void of hate, but killing him just the same"... he means that Devo loves him, but he's still hurting Maynard because of Maynard's past.... 
When he talks about "snake behind me hisses, what my damage could have been", he's talkin about how what his father did to him wants to resurge through him and onto Devo. then the next verse "my blood before me begs me, open up my heart again"... he's sayin that the blood before him (his children, future grandchildren, etc.) is begging him to forget the past and start over... Infer the rest of the song for yourself. I think this is the best explanation possible.
im not disrespecting anyone elses theorys, and if i said that it was un intentional, im just making the point that this is what it ACTUALLY means. it may mean something different to you, and thats kool. you can express the song the way you want to but just dont say that thats what it meant to manyard

Ok I aint saying anyone is wrong, it is a personalthing. But here's some things i dug up in various articles.

First look is at Maynardâs background.He has a son called Devo. He was christened Devo H Keenen. What the H stands for is unknown, but the song obviously has something to do with his son and/or his birth. 

 The second angle is drawn from many of the Tool concerts. As Maynard is about to start the song, he talks about the old Warner Bros Cartoons. He recounts when the angel and the devil are on each shoulder and tell him to make a decision. Maynard says itâs a no-brainer, as the angel obviously has the right decision. 
 Maynard then snaps back to reality and reminds us that life isnât always that easy, and that peopleâs opinions and suggestions arenât always right or true, so ultimately you should make the decision for yourself. 

So what if the two theories were combined. Maybe, Maynard was advised to raise his child with some issue, or maybe to have him at all. Ultimately, the song is about making choices for yourself, and how Maynard realised this, and it turned out for the better.

I like what  Madison4562 had to say about this song. I was going to say basically the same thing but he/she did a very nice job already. 

I'm a parent myself but I was one of the results of a very bad, never ending, hell marriage (that being the relationship of my parents) My mother is a manically depressed alcoholic, so our life was always packed full of mom induced drama.

I hated the drama and everything she would put us all through when she was in one of her "moods" I always told myself I would never be like that, I would never do that to my children. 

Although I am no where near as bad as my mother, it's something that I have to struggle for. It's a constant battle inside, constantly pushing down the rage and  making myself be a good mom. I get better at it every day but it's not easy and there are days when I get the urge to sneak away and never look back because some small part of me tells me I never should have had kids and I might have made a mistake. But then the depressed trapped feelings go away and I know that my children are better off with me and I know that they are worth the constant struggle inside to be a good parent. I know that having well adjusted, healthy, happy children is worth the battle to be a better mother, then my mother was to me. 

It's very hard to a parent when your own childhood was traumatic, the very act of parenting can be daily reminder of how fucked up things use to be when you were a child.

comment_133:
One of my favorite TooL songs. I read an interpretation in the forums of one of the TooL websites that sounds pretty much perfect to me. It's really long, but it's thorough.

What's coming through is alive.
The baby being brought into the world is a life he created.

What's holding up is a mirror.
The baby is like a reflection or mirror image of him.

But what's singing songs is a snake looking to turn this piss to wine.
But there's a voice in the back of his head telling him to leave his son's life for the sake of his own, looking to turn a bad situation into a good one.

They're both totally void of hate, but killing me just the same.
The temptation to leave his son's life is not because he dislikes him, but that dosent make the decision any easier.

The snake behind me hisses what my damage could have been.
He hears the side of the decision that tells him what oppertunities he will be leaving behind and the things he will be giving up if he decides to take a child into his life.

My blood before me begs me open up my heart again.
Seing his son before him makes him lose all his defenses and want to accept him into his life.

And I feel this coming over like a storm again.
He feels the decision coming over his conciousness like a storm.

considerately.
But not because of hate, which is why it is so hard, all his son wants is love.

Venomous voice, tempts me, drains me, bleeds me, leaves me cracked and empty.
The side of him that wants him to leave his child leaves him exhausted, tempting him with the posabilities of his life staying the same.

Drags me down like some sweet gravity.
Concideratly brings him down, but not because of hate or negative emotions.

The snake behind me hisses what my damage could have been.
The side of him that tempts him to leave his child reminds him what he could be giving up by accepting Devo into his life.

My blood before me begs me open up my heart again.
Seeing his son in front of him makes him drop all his guards.

And I feel this coming over like a storm again.
He feels the decision coming over his conciousness like a storm, in waves.

I am too connected to you to slip away, to fade away.
He realizes he loves his son too much to let him slip out of his life.

Days away I still feel you touching me, changing me, and considerately killing me.
He realizes that seeing a life he has made is changing him, purifying and transforming his soul while at the same time killing the person he used to be and possabilites he is leaving behind.

Without the skin, beneath the storm, under these tears the walls came down.
He breaks down and cries, realizing he can't hold up the walls against his son forever because he loves him too much.

And the snake is drowned and as I look in his eyes, my fear begins to fade recalling all of those times.
The part of him that tempted him to leave his son is gone, and looking at him he begins to realize all the times he wasted that could have been full a happiness because of his love for his son.

I could have cried then.
He could have accepted his son his son into his life much sooner and felt all these wonderfull emotions before.

I should have cried then.
He should have accepted his son sooner and let the positive emotions take ahold of him.

And as the walls come down and as I look in your eyes my fear begins to fade recalling all of the times I have died and will die.
He looks at his son and realizes that everyone has a father, and everyone deserves to know their father and that it's okay that he is that person, because he dident like it when his mother left him when he was 11.

It's all right.
It's allright that he is Devo's father.

I don't mind.
He dosent mind being a father.

I am too connected to you to slip away, to fade away.
He loves his son too much to fade out of his life.

Days away I still feel you touching me, changing me, and considerately killing me.
And although he has accepted his son into his life and it's a wonderful thing, he still somtimes wonders what could have been if he hadn't.

comment_165:
I know there are many meanings behind this song (which is what makes it so beautiful). It could be about a past love, Maynard's son, and it does point to heroin. 

With the latter, I don't think it is about that because from what I've known, Maynard's never been addicted to drugs. When he wrote "Weak and Powerless" he said in an interview that it was difficult to write for him since he hasn't been addicted to drugs. He had to write that song using the experiences of people he knew. Not his own. Still, if that's what it means to you and it helps you with you own life, that's great.

I think the meaning about his son makes the most since, but I can't relate to it as easily as others. That's why I found a different meaning: temptation.

It's quite obvious that the snake is meant to symbolize temptation (a reference to Genesis, as been's stated before). The snake makes promises ("turning piss into wine") which sound good, but they are bad for you.

The blood before him could mean his family trying to help him out and steer him on the right path. It all kinda goes back to the thing about an angel on one side and a devil on the other.

Just my thoughts.

I'm sorry, but having done heroin before and seeing people falling into the depths of heroin abuse, not to mention analyzing the lyrics to this song over and over again, there is no dount in my mind that it is about heroin. I mean, it fits all too well. All of you people that are trying to change it into his son, come on ... thats looking WAY too deep into things.

You said Maynard refrenced an angel and devil to this song? Well ... that is exactly the battle that heroin addicts have. They know they shouldnt do it ... but that snake beside them convinces them.

"
The snake behind me hisses
What my damage could have been
My blood before me begs me
Open up my heart again
"

"
And as the walls come down and
As I look in your eyes
My fear begins to fade
Recalling all of the times
I have died
and will die
It's all right
I don't mind
"

"
I am too connected to you to
Slip away, to fade away

"

Come on ... if this isn't heroin then I'm just crazy.

comment_214:
the heroin methaphor is the simple meaning behind the song. simple, but yet so powerful. i've had a a few addictive problems, nothing like heroin but at the same time they've fucked over my life somewhat. listening to this song this morning, i almost cried, which is something i never do. this song is helping me gain the strength not to fall back upon those addictions.

"And I feel this coming over like a storm again"
to me this represents that craving that one encounters when doing something that is addictive for them. when you try that substance (or whatever else it may be), it is as if there is a voice (venomous) that sucks you into a hole (the storm), the destructive chaos that takes over your life

"I am too connected to you to
Slip away, to fade away
Days away I still feel you
Touching me, changing me,"
anyone who has experienced addiction knows very well that no matter how well they treat themselves, there will always be that addictive clinging to that substance ("days away I still feel you"). the old saying "once an alcoholic, always an alcoholic" applies here pretty well (in my interpretation of course). even a mere taste, and you feel yourself changing back to that destructive state you had led in the past. it is all due to a strong connection that is formed between your desires and the substance that you are addicted to ("I am too connected to you to"), and you must realize that you will never be able to shed this connectivity between yourself and the substance.

"And the snake is drowned and
As I look in his eyes,
My fear begins to fade
Recalling all of those times"
you have broken free of the substance, and you wonder how you could have let yourself fall. you gain courage from this, and continue to remember the times on that substance. a friend of mine, speaking about him quiting marijuana had told me "you'll always have the memories" and yes the memories can be wonderful, but you must always keep in mind the destructiveness that came along due to the addiction.

thanks tool, for writing music, for opening our eyes, for providing us with a manner of looking within ourselves and discovering.

comment_240:
I respectfully disagree with Madson's explanation.

And I completely denounce all the "It's about Heroin" answers.

While, yes, the song could be literally interpreted as being about Heroin, but listening to Tool should tell you that while, literally, a lot of the lyrics are about simple things, you should never, ever, take their lyrics literally. It always has some kind of abstract meaning.

I think it has to do about being hurt my someone, and closing yourself off to being hurt again by anyone else. I think it has to do with being hurt, and expecting to be hurt or harmed again by someone else, even if your instincts tell you to give them a chance, 

'My blood before me begs me
Open up my heart again
And I feel this coming over like a storm again'

I think the song tells two stories in a mixed up order. It both reconnects with the past experience of being hurt,

'I am too connected to you to
Slip away, to fade away
Days away I still feel you
Touching me, changing me,
And considerately killing me
And considerately killing me
And considerately killing me
And considerately killing me'

and also tells a story about how that has shaped and affected his ability to open up to another person, or even that very same person for a second chance,

'And as the walls come down and
As I look in your eyes
My fear begins to fade
Recalling all of the times
I have died
and will die
It's all right
I don't mind
I don't mind
I don't mind'

But that's just my own personal interpretation of the song. I find Tool is the best when you look to your own interpretation, not those of other people.
comment_241:
Right, I think that madson is right with that interpretation, but the word metaphysical can be applied to a song like this, as in it deliberately has multiple layers of meaning. 

I personally like to look at this song as a battle against heroin. Maynard uses contrasting imagery of 'piss' and 'wine' in the first verse, showing how to him heroin is both a filthy liquid and at the same time one that is both sweet and precious. 'both totally void of hate' - hypodermics?? im not sure about that one, 'killing me just the same' should be obvious though.

'My blood before me begs me, Open up my heart again' - this again is easily linked to shooting up, but the language used, specifically the word 'beg' and the phrase 'tempts me' in the line before suggests that Maynard is trying to fight against the urge to use heroin

the analysis can go on... 'leaves me cracked and empty' - the comedown is obviously harsh with a drug like heroin. 'drags me down like some sweet gravity' - we've all seen trainspotting right? that bit where ewan mcgregor shoots up and seems to sink into the floor? might be something similar..

'too connected to you to slip away' - shows how maynard feels he is dependent on the drug and cannot  get off it.
'days away i feel you touching me' - perhaps a reference to the lasting effects of heroin


and this is the bit that could make or break this interpretation

'i feel this coming over like a storm again.'
if we take 'storm' here to mean the hit you recieve from heroin, then this rolls into the next stanza:

'without the skin
beneath the storm
under these tears
the walls came down'

if you switch the words 'without' and 'beneath' around, and already take storm to mean a hit from heroin, we can interpret the walls coming down to mean the horrible experience of going 'cold turkey' when you're addicted to smack (without the storm)

anyways i might be totally wrong, but i think the references are too easy to spot and the links too easy to make for this to be totally unintentional.. plus as someone already mentioned heroin does indeed begin with the letter 'H'.

comment_245:
To me this song is about the R-complex, or the reptilian part of the human brain.  The R-complex developed first in reptiles(hence the name) along the course of evolution and still exists in the human being.  The line "the snake behind me hisses" points to the past, or earlier stages of evolution - "what my damage could have been" suggests the fact that the R-complex is more inclined to animalistic behaviors.  "My blood before me begs me, open up my heart again" strongly suggests reaching into the neocortex to overcome our primitive behavior, keeping in mind that we are on an evolutionary course, so keep the future in mind.

The way he talks of drowning the snake is more evidence of this meaning.

"Recalling all of the times I have died and will die" suggests to me the stages of evolution.  Keep in mind the early forms of human life are now extinct.  Who's to say that our current state of existence is not permanent and will be replaced by the next stage, in a sense die.

So in effect this song is about abandoning our more instinctual tendencies to embrace rather a more heart felt state of being, so that we can usher in the next stage of evolution.  That stage is more of a higher consciousness state of being.

As a side note I like to think most of Maynard's lyrics are more encompassing to the human species, rather than just a personal meaning to Maynard.

The thing that came into line for them is they couldn't be together because people would find it 'weird', and it's considerately killing the both of them while they're still happy no matter what, being able to look into each other's eyes and say it's alright. Either-way, I love this song. It's awesome.

comment_267:
This song is definitely about Heroin. Whether Maynard used heroin or not is not important. Maynard has stated that when he writes, he often writes songs about other people and changes the 'You' to 'Me' for greater effect. 

The "snake" reference alludes to the creationism story of Adam and the forbidden fruit (Heroin). He is then tempted and overwhelmed with feeling to give in. 

"Drains me, bleeds me,
Leaves me cracked and empty".

Literal and metaphorical drain of life and blood loss when injecting intravenously. Literal cracks in the injection site and a metaphorical feeling of emptiness.

"Drags me down like some sweet gravity".

His drug use is bittersweet. In the long run, the drug is bringing him down. But when he's high he experiences this 'sweet gravity'

"I am too connected to you
To slip away, fade away.
Days away I still feel you
Touching me, changing me"

His addiction is getting out of hand. Days when he tries to abstain from use, he can feel the symptoms of withdrawal. 'Touching me, changing me', I'm sure we've all known or have seen someone with an addiction change into a completely different person because of the drug's hold on the individual. 

"Considerately killing me."

Heroin is literally deteriorating his body and organs.  

He begins to cry and finds it therapeutic. The temptation to indulge in this drug is drowned for now.

"I could have cried then.
I should have cried then."

He reflects that he could have cried to relieve whatever tension was in his life and that he should have indeed cried rather than inject heroin. 

However, the drug has too strong a grip on him and he doesn't mind that he will die.

comment_272:
Tool addresses subject matter from four different levels at a time. Interpreting this song involves looking at it from more than one angle. Sure, we have definitely established all of these angles to be valid, respectively. I find it odd that no one weaves them together. Maybe it is an intentional move on the artists' parts to disperse the truth of the matter in order to make it as relevant as possible. To me it is simply a matter of choices and how we learn. You make one choice that comes from ignorance, and then you learn from the result. Your next choice is bound to be wiser, yet you still carry the Karma from your foolish choice. So it is about the struggle to do what is right. I hate to say it, but I think the entire band simply utilizes their own experiences to reflect said subject matter. Not the other way around. Sorry.

Thanks.

My interpretation:
"Maynard" was the image created by the man James Keenan..some say it is his middle name or a nickname given to him by some friends or his changed name, but not exactly sure. comment_276:
I always had an idea that this song was about performing on stage, and how you have to put on a persona in order to do that.  It comes over you "like a storm", and the process of opening your heart and baring your soul to the crowd uses you up and "leaves me cracked and empty", and he compares it to dying and being reborn over and over again.  Eventually the person that you are on stage bleeds into the person that you are off stage and they become so connected that you can no longer seperate the two, even to yourself, so in a sense the person that you are becoming "kills" the person that you used to be.

Anyway, that's what the song always meant to me...I've read some other pretty compelling explanations here but I'll probably stick with my own interpretation.  The fact that the lyrics are ambiguous enough to be interpreted by different people in ways that are meaningful to them is one of the things that makes Tool so amazing.

comment_288:
I think that a lot of Tool songs are really open to interpretation. To me, even if it wasn't Maynard's intention, this song is about heroin. My  first clue was obviously the title. I listened to this song a lot while was in rehab recovering from my own heroin addicton and it was crazy how much I found myself relating to it. This is how I interprated the lyrics:


" totally void of hate, but killing me just the same" --heroin is an inanimate object, it can't hate, it can't seek revenge, it can't 
                                                                                feel at all, but it is still capable of destroying lives 

"the snake behind me hisses"-------------------- the snake is a metaphor for heroin and/or his addiction

"what my damage could have been"--------------- his addiction could have caused more damage to his life than it already had or 
                                                                                eventually killed him 

"my blood before me begs open up my heart again"--his body(his"blood") "begs" for the drug to be back flowing
                                                                                  through his heart 

"and I feel this coming over like a storm again"-------he fees his addiction rising up and coming back to tempt him

"I am too connected to you to slip away, to fade away"-he is too mentally and physically addicted to forget about heroin and move   
                                                                                  on

"days away I still feel you touching me, changing me"- even after going days without using heroin he can still feel the  
                                                                                  mental and physical effects of withdrawal 

"and considerately killing me"--------------------- heroin is killing him "considerately", going back to the idea that it is an inanimate 
                                                                                  object, incapable of intent to kill but deadly none the less

"venomous voice, tempts me"--------------------- the "venomous voice" relates back to the snake/heroin metaphor

"drains me, bleeds me"-------------------------- a reference to shooting up

"drags me down like some sweet gravity"----------- he nods off on heroin and is physically "drag[ged]" down as if by 
                                                                                 gravity( specifically a "sweet" gravity which could be a reference to  
                                                                                 the "sweet" euphoric feeing of nodding out ) 

"and as the walls come down and as I look
in your eyes my fear begins to fade"----------------- "the walls come down" and he gets a peak nto the depth and ugliness of 
                                                                                  his addiction. He looks into the eyes(which are said to show truth)  
                                                                                  of the snake and sees the pure destructive nature of the creature( which is 
                                                                                  a metaphor of destructiveness of his addiction). His gained 
                                                                                  insight causes him to start feeing more in control and less powerless over his 
                                                                                  addiction.  

"recalling all of the times I have died"---------------- his "fear begins to fade" as he remembers the dangerous life or death 
                                                                                  situations that being a heroin addict has put him in. "All the times I have died" 
                                                                                  could refer to close call overdoses where he might have technically died before 
                                                                                  being brought back to life.  


"It's all right I don't mind"------------------------ he doesn't mind dying because he is high on heroin which can make  
                                                                                 users fee apathetic, relatively numb towards the world

"and considerately killing me"--------------------- the song ends on a negative note that could suggest that the subject is still
                                                                                 being "considerately kill[ed]" by his addiction  

So thats what I get out of it. Maynard might have not been thinking about heroin at all while writing this, but that ls definitely the first thing that popped into my head when I read the lyrics...but thats only my opinion of course, and hey i wont deny the possibility that my interpretation could be nothing more than my junkie mind's uncanny ability to relate heroin to everything.....

comment_297:
The "H" is anything. It's whatever vile thing has a hold of you. Whether it's heroin, alcohol, a man/woman or even something more sinister. Think Keith Moon's addiction, Nabokov's Lolita or Dexter's Dark Passenger. Whatever horrible, self-destructive thing you just can't quit, that's "H".  It's the thing that has the venomous voice that tempts you and then drains you, bleeds you and leaves you cracked and empty. And this song, is about the doleful fact that when you are faced with such a beast, you're going to lose. You just will.

However, there is good news. As soon as you lose that battle (which you will). Once you *finally* give in to that craving, once you realize that there is no immovable object with which to battle the irresistible force and just let yourself *be* â you won't care. You won't even remember why you thought that thing that had you was so horrible in the first place. And that's because your new realityâwhere you exist nowâwill be using that horrible black thing which once held such sway over you as its new baseline for normality. But don't worry, it's alright, you don't mind.
comment_298:
I believe this song is about life and death. The "H" standing for Heaven and Hell. Most if not all cultures have defined their lives through religion. Knowing Maynard's thoughts on religion i think the meaning is really deep. 

I think the first line is: "What's coming through is a lie. not "alive." "What's holding up is a mirror." This is to say that we ourselves create the reality of this world and that everything you see id but a refection of your and everyone elses thoughts. This is about how no matter what the religion or thoughts about a god and a devil it's a lie cause we cannot define what life and existence really is. We try through religion to give us purpose thusly defining our existence. 

When he says that they're both void of hate and killing me just the same. He's talking about god and the devil not really hating us but that for each we must die. Religious debate aside there are those who feel the devil also loved us and that by showing eve the way to a higher level of consciousness so that we aren't simple monkeys like it seems god wanted us to be.

When he says that he feels it coming over like a storm he's talking about dying and that no matter what the form "change the way, I still feel you" he still feels the existence of what we would call god. but not split up into good and evil. when he speaks about being without the skin here, beneath the storm hes talking about that place when you die. the storm is the storm of life and all the things that go on in it. Time there has no bounds, the walls of existence itself come down, and he is able to see his past lives.

He talks about when the snake is dry, (when this life is over.) The snake of life behind him hisses what his life could have been. And his blood, his flesh begging to open his heart and live again. 

As the snake is dry, There's a look in his (god) eyes, my fear begins to fade, recalling all of the times he dies. He thinks about times where he could have cried about dying that way. and the times when he should have cried about his death. And as he comes to realize the true nature of existence he doesn't mind dying again. I visualize crazy death scenes in the guitar solo part where he thinks about the hundreds of times he's lived and died. at the end he starts again saying that "I sense someone killing me." He starts again in a new form.
Change the way, I still feel you touching me, changing me.

That's just my personal interpretation..
Big Tool fan and probably the only black guy at their concerts. lol....
comment_299: Folks - not to diminish the value of your speculation about his son and this and that, but I must tell you that someone who has been up to .5gr of H + .2gr of Ck in a single shot 3 times a day the meaning of the song is beyond transparent. Unfortunately, it is impossible to convey that confidence and clarity to someone who has not been through the waves and cycles of multi-dimensional sensations associated with the above lifestyle. comment_300: H. is the abbreviation for heroin used in Aleister Crowley's "Diary of a Drug Fiend." Perhaps the song "H." references both the drug and the book, or Crowley himself.
comment_301: This song fit perfectly into my experience loving someone who didn't love me back... trying to let her go. Didn't even know what H stood for til I read it here.
comment_302:
You know what I love about Tool's music? It can be interpreted in SO many ways! No one is wrong or right...Maynard likes it that way too. 
When I first heard this song, I believed it was about heroin.  At the time, my ex boyfriend had a really bad problem with it, so it made sense to me.  After going through a horrible, almost torturous breakup, plus many months of heartache and confusion after, I found new meaning in the song.  
I think that's the whole point too.  Tool's music is meant to be seen through ALL eyes at different times of our lives. 
Keep your third eye open.

comment_306:
I agree with most of the other posters that it's about his son and his struggle to try and break the cycle that he went through as a child and try to be there for his son (both physically and emotionally).

What's coming through is alive. (a baby coming out of the womb)
What's holding up is a mirror.  (the newborn is a reflection of himself)
But what's singing songs is a snake (referring to himself/career)
Looking to turn this piss to wine. (trying to make the best of the cards he was dealt)

Much of the rest is about his turmoil about trying to do the right thing by his son, and not follow in the footsteps of his upbringing. 

I am too connected to you to (his son)
Slip away, to fade away. (he won't leave like his father did)
Days away I still feel you (on tour/on the road, still thinking about his child)
Touching me, changing me, 
And considerately killing me. (wondering if him being on the road/tour all the time is any different than his father being out of the picture, and how that will affect his son)
Without the skin, (shedding the thick skin he's grown to adapt survive his situation/upbringing)
Beneath the storm, (the anger/hate he carried with him
Under these tears  
The walls came down. (self-explanatory....breaking down in emotion and letting your guard down and accepting who/what you are)

And the snake is drowned and (letting go of the demons/hatred that he carried)
As I look in his eyes,
My fear begins to fade
Recalling all of those times.
I could have cried then.
I should have cried then.  (realizing that he should of let his emotion overtake him a long time ago, rather than carry them around, eating at him)
And as the walls come down and
As I look in your eyes (his child's)
My fear begins to fade
Recalling all of the times
I have died
And will die.
It's all right.
I don't mind.  (these last 5-6 lines are again about owning his past, but realizing that it doesn't have to define him and that he can decide any future he wishes for he and his son's relationship, and will do whatever is necessary to make sure it's not like his was)
comment_307:
It's understandable that this song would be hard to understand since it's about (imo) a fairly common but far from universal emotional disorder that most people cannot relate to personally.  When someone is abused as a child they will suppress the emotional pain and feel another emotion instead, in my case anger.  But you can't bury your emotions forever ("I am too connected to you to slip away, fade away") so when that emotional tank is full the dam breaks and it all comes pouring out and you feel months of emotional pain condensed into a very short period, in which you flash back to painful periods where you should've felt your feelings.  The snake is the pain he's carrying around, the song is about the mixed feeling of the intense agony of feeling the outpouring of emotional pain with the sense of relief at being able to feel with a part of you that has been numb for so long and being able to unburden yourself, thus "considerately killing me".  "And as the snake is drowned, and as I look in his eyes my fear begins to fade, recalling all of the times I could have cried then... I should have cried then, and as the walls come down and as I look in your eyes my fear begins to fade, recalling all of the times I have died, and will die - it's alright, I don't mind."  As someone who experienced this many times growing up it is a profoundly beautiful and poetic (not to mention deep and thoughtful) description of the whole experience.

Though like with all art, any meaning you get out of it through other interpretations is still meaningful - but this describes the emotional disorder in question so well and so specifically that it's hard to subscribe to the other interpretations I've read.

This song is definitely about Maynards son, but its not about how he wants to abuse his child, wtf thats ridiculous.

This song is about a man being forced to face his past, to accept how he was raised and doing what he can to avoid becoming the emotionless father he had himself.

comment_312: Allow youre self emotions and dont hold em in .. no one is made out of stone, especially us guys with humans tradition of bringing up a male child to be " Rambo "
comment_313:
Of course, there is Maynard's meaning.  However, songs mean different things to different people and move us each in a unique ways.  I believe it could very well be about heroin addiction, but I think it can also be about co-dependency in relationships. 

 Like when someone is so attached to someone since they feel such emptiness, but they become very distressed when they sense distance (i.e. I am too connected to you to slip away fade away).  I think the beginning part about temptation is when someone is tempted into a relationship that may be toxic, but they proceed anyway, becoming addicted to the person who fills a void for them.  They try to keep their feelings in check (hence, "Days away I still feel you touching me, changing me.  Considerately killing me").  The person knows they are in over their head and that their emotions are being controlled by their attachment to someone.  It is killing them, but they choose to bear with the pain. They are empty, and afraid; not knowing what else to do, so they hold on, and the cycle continues.
comment_314: The lyrics of this song always made me think of Jesus in the desert, being tempted by Satan, and the resolution  that Jesus  faced while on the cross. The title of the song, "H" was something that I did not understand.   Looking back I probably got it all wrong, it probably has more to do with his personal relationship with his child, or  perhaps a poetic expression about heroin addiction.   Either way, all of us identify with the feelings expressed in our own personal way .
comment_315:
Well, I have been listening to this song and album since I was 14, I am now 32 and believe you me I have changed my opinion of this song many times depending on the knowledge and experience I have gained throughout my years.

I believe it IS about his abusive past and his son BUT, I believe it is also coming from a more spiritually enlightened point of view. The "snake" he refers to is indeed from his Stepfather but is NOT his stepfather. Let me explain further.

Maynard obviously sold his soul to the Devil to make this record, as he bluntly expresses in "Hooker with a penis" on selling your soul the truth of reality is reveled to you by a God (not Lord God) and you start to understand things that you never knew before, like the fact that a demon can travel through your family line and cause abuse, suicide, mental illness etc passing down through your family tie's, this can happen if a rule is severely broken, a sin (Lord Gods Law) .

Maynard knows this because of what he bought into, eyes opened and truths reveled. So, with this extensive knowledge he is very much afraid of the snake (Demon) that influenced his step Dad as it could possibly influence himself, and therefore his son and so on. This happens in a spiritual realm, when you are abused spiritually, your wounds are opened to the abuser. 

If you really feel and listen to what this album is about, you know it's not about just the physical realm but the hidden ones he has dabbled in.

comment_317:
The Fall of Man

1 What's coming through is alive.
2 What's holding up is a mirror.
3 But what's singing songs is a snake, it is,
4 Looking to turn my piss to wine.
5 They're both totally void of hate, and,
6 Killing me just the same.

1/2 Whats appearing is "alive" and has a mirroring effect
(Made in God's image)

3  The snake (Satan/Temptation) is tempting and alluring. Inviting and coaxing with flattering words and with the power of an ancient muse/siren. The temptation to learn and have wisdom and free will has become enticing

4
 The snake has the ability to produce mirages and illusions. Offering to provide Eve/Adam with knowledge and the power of free-will 

5
 Both God and Satan are void of intentional hate and ill will. Both wish to make Adam/Eve in their image.

6 However, both Deities have condemned the two. (a)The eating of the apple provided them additional knowledge, but it also gave them the ability to conjure negative and destructive concepts such as shame and evil. (b)This act of rebellion (free thinking/free will) eventually leads to their expulsion, manual labor and pain in childbirth.

--------------------------------------------------------------------

1 The snake behind me hisses,
2 What my damage could have been.
3 My blood before me begs me,
4 Open up my heart again.

1 The tempter/temptress is no longer singing a lovely melody of false, it is now a demand. 
2 The narrator is presented with the "damage" of not eating of the Tree of Knowledge; bliss,ignorance, complacency,etc.
3/4  Adam's blood (rib/Eve) begs Him to also partake of the forbidden fruit. The pomegranate is the passion fruit, also called the food of love. The pomegranate is believed by many to be the true forbidden fruit, not the apple. This fruit stains that are similar to blood stains.
(Still you pray, you never stray
. Never taste of the fruit
)
(You never thought to question why/"Judith")
----------------------------------------------------------------------------

And I feel this coming over like a storm again, considerately...

1 Having been tempted the consideration (considerately) to gain additional knowledge, to think for one's self, and the overall temptation in general has led Adam/Eve to consider the possibilities and weigh the decisions (brainstorm) (As below, so above and beyond, I imagine
Drawn beyond the lines of reason
. Push the envelope, watch it bend/There is so much more
And beckons me to look through to these infinite possibilities
/"Lateralus). This could be the Serpent tempting Eve or Eve tempting Adam.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------

1 Venomous voice tempts me,
2 And drains me, bleeds me,
3 Leaves me cracked and empty,
4 Drags me down like some sweet gravity.

1 Adam's own conscience has now become the voice of temptation as He now indulges in the Fruit. 
2 The Fruit has now opened Adam's eyes to the world around Him. 
3 His Third Eye is no longer blind (to the "naked eye") and He is fully aware of right and wrong. He now has a sense of guilt and understanding. Adam/Eve then cover themselves in "leaves". The Union with God is "cracked and the Garden is now "empty" of luxuries.
4 Adam/Eve now experience guilt, shame, disgrace and depression (drags me down)
Adam is now doomed to till the Earth and toil the soil
The Serpent was also "cursed to the ground" to crawl 
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

1 I am too connected to you to slip away, fade away.
2 Days away I still feel you touching me, changing me and 

1. Connected by the rib (under the arm/care) the Two are inseparable. They are also forever bonded to God having been made in His Image.
2. Days after the Expulsion they are still being "touched" by their "Creators" hand and being changed into who they have now become, yet always with the ability to "change"
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Considerately killing me.

The Creator still seems to be punishing the Two
Longing and lamentation over having been expelled

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Without the skin here,
Beneath the storm.
Under these tears now,
The walls came down.

From the Creator's perspective:
Without the Creation in the Garden there is now a void and a sadness. The walls that once separated God's Children from the outside world is now non existent
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Once the snake is drowned and as I look in his eyes,
My fear begins to fade,
Recalling all of the times I could have cried then.
I should have cried then.

As the walls come down and as I look in your eyes,
My fear begins to fade,
Recalling all of the times I have died, and will die.
It's alright.

I don't mind.

Adam/Eve now fully understand to gain this knowledge and truly be free the Fruit had to be eaten. With knowledge comes responsibility. There is no gain without pain. Once the snake becomes a figment of the imagination it ceases to hold power and sway. They recall all the times They could have cried and did not because it was never necessary. Both Good and Evil need to exist. The mental wall, the fear, the obstacles come down. They accept They could have died and will eventually die. This is freedom. It's alright, it's inevitable. They don't mind.

3  The snake (Satan/Temptation) is tempting and alluring. Inviting and coaxing with flattering words and with the power of an ancient muse/siren. The temptation to learn and have wisdom and free will has become enticing

4
 The snake has the ability to produce mirages and illusions. Offering to provide Eve/Adam with knowledge and the power of free-will 

5
 Both God and Satan are void of intentional hate and ill will. Both wish to make Adam/Eve in their image.

6 However, both Deities have condemned the two. (a)The eating of the apple provided them additional knowledge, but it also gave them the ability to conjure negative and destructive concepts such as shame and evil. (b)This act of rebellion (free thinking/free will) eventually leads to their expulsion, manual labor and pain in childbirth.

--------------------------------------------------------------------

1 The snake behind me hisses,
2 What my damage could have been.
3 My blood before me begs me,
4 Open up my heart again.

1 The tempter/temptress is no longer singing a lovely melody of false, it is now a demand. 
2 The narrator is presented with the "damage" of not eating of the Tree of Knowledge; bliss,ignorance, complacency,etc.
3/4  Adam's blood (rib/Eve) begs Him to also partake of the forbidden fruit. The pomegranate is the passion fruit, also called the food of love. The pomegranate is believed by many to be the true forbidden fruit, not the apple. This fruit stains that are similar to blood stains.
(Still you pray, you never stray
. Never taste of the fruit
)
(You never thought to question why/"Judith")
----------------------------------------------------------------------------

And I feel this coming over like a storm again, considerately...

1 Having been tempted the consideration (considerately) to gain additional knowledge, to think for one's self, and the overall temptation in general has led Adam/Eve to consider the possibilities and weigh the decisions (brainstorm) (As below, so above and beyond, I imagine
Drawn beyond the lines of reason
. Push the envelope, watch it bend/There is so much more
And beckons me to look through to these infinite possibilities
/"Lateralus). This could be the Serpent tempting Eve or Eve tempting Adam.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------

1 Venomous voice tempts me,
2 And drains me, bleeds me,
3 Leaves me cracked and empty,
4 Drags me down like some sweet gravity.

1 Adam's own conscience has now become the voice of temptation as He now indulges in the Fruit. 
2 The Fruit has now opened Adam's eyes to the world around Him. 
3 His Third Eye is no longer blind (to the "naked eye") and He is fully aware of right and wrong. He now has a sense of guilt and understanding. Adam/Eve then cover themselves in "leaves". The Union with God is "cracked and the Garden is now "empty" of luxuries.
4 Adam/Eve now experience guilt, shame, disgrace and depression (drags me down)
Adam is now doomed to till the Earth and toil the soil
The Serpent was also "cursed to the ground" to crawl 
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

1 I am too connected to you to slip away, fade away.
2 Days away I still feel you touching me, changing me and 

1. Connected by the rib (under the arm/care) the Two are inseparable. They are also forever bonded to God having been made in His Image.
2. Days after the Expulsion they are still being "touched" by their "Creators" hand and being changed into who they have now become, yet always with the ability to "change"
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Considerately killing me.

The Creator still seems to be punishing the Two
Longing and lamentation over having been expelled

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Without the skin here,
Beneath the storm.
Under these tears now,
The walls came down.

From the Creator's perspective:
Without the Creation in the Garden there is now a void and a sadness. The walls that once separated God's Children from the outside world is now non existent
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Once the snake is drowned and as I look in his eyes,
My fear begins to fade,
Recalling all of the times I could have cried then.
I should have cried then.

As the walls come down and as I look in your eyes,
My fear begins to fade,
Recalling all of the times I have died, and will die.
It's alright.

I don't mind.

Adam/Eve now fully understand to gain this knowledge and truly be free the Fruit had to be eaten. With knowledge comes responsibility. There is no gain without pain. Once the snake becomes a figment of the imagination it ceases to hold power and sway. They recall all the times They could have cried and did not because it was never necessary. Both Good and Evil need to exist. The mental wall, the fear, the obstacles come down. They accept They could have died and will eventually die. This is freedom. It's alright, it's inevitable. They don't mind.

THESE TWO ARE YOUR FRIENDS GIVING YOU CONFLICTING ADVICE ABOUT LOVE.  THE SNAKE BEHIND ME, THATS THE NAYSAYERS.  MY BLOOD BEFORE ME, THOSE ARE THE PEOPLE TELLING HIM TO OPEN UP AND TRY AGAIN. comment_328:
Whatever this means to anyone else, and the meanings everyone has provided seem valid and lovely... this song has a huge meaning to me.
When I was very young I had a series of horrible love relationships until I finally spent two years with a man who abused and neglected me and when he cheated on me and left me I was done, I was broken. I built myself up with walls all around and I would let no one in, approx. a year after that I met another man who tried to get me to open up to him and it took him forever but it finally worked and this song helped me realize that I have died, and will die again, so I needed to open my heart up literally. Every line has an important meaning to me and when he played it for me it helped me so much. Four years later I'm a healthier happier independent individual with a successful relationship. So even if it's painful to others to me this song is a reminder to me that pain is okay and must be overcome.
